div.p: This implementation guide is based on the HL7 FHIR standard. It uses terminology, notations and design principles that are specific to FHIR. Before reading this implementation guide, it is important to be familiar with some of the basic principles of FHIR as well as general guidance on how to read FHIR specifications. Readers who are unfamiliar with FHIR are encouraged to read (or at least skim) the following prior to reading the rest of this implementation guide.

li.a: How to read resource & profile definitions

div.p: Feel free to explore other aspects of the FHIR specification that you feel may be relevant or of interest.

This implementation guide defines profiles on several resources. It also leverages profiles from underlying guides. Where implementers adhere to one of the profiles defined in this guide, they will also need to adhere to the base expectations defined in the profiled resource. The table below lists all resources used as part of the current IG and indicates where they are used, as well as which profiles apply. Implementers are strongly encouraged to read through the introductions and implementation notes associated with each resource they will implement, though not all resource guidance will necessarily apply in the context of implementing this guide.

Used to indicate a performer of a referal and/or to indicate what delivery organization a given provider works for. Referenced by many of the other resources.

Used to indicate the subject of care - i.e. the individual being assisted in improving or sustaining their levels of physical activity. For discussion on the use of the word 'patient', see the Design Considerations page.

An individual involved in the care delivery process, independent of what organization they work for or what 'hat' they are wearing. Used in most resources to represent requesters, performers, etc. For further discussion of practitioners, see the Design Considerations page.

Someone involved in the care delivery process with the ability to identify the specific individual, the organization they are working for, and/or the 'hat' they are wearing. Used in most resources to represent requesters, performers, etc. when more than just the individual is relevant. For further discussion of practitioners, see the Design Considerations page.

Allows sharing a specific form to be filled out by a patient or caregiver as part of the care coordination process. Used as part of the Patient Task process described in the SDOH Patient Coordination Workflow.
Allows sharing a partially or fully completed formform that was filled out by a patient or caregiver. Used as part of the Patient Task process described in the SDOH Patient Coordination Workflow.

Allows capturing the participation of caregivers such as family members or neighbors (rather than only the patient) in the process - as authors, performers, subjects, etc. For more information on the involvement of caregivers, see the Design Considerations page.
Physical Activity

Can be used to represent either an exercise prescription - an order for physical activity directed at the patient, or a referral - a request for another provider or organization to assist with the patient's physical activity in some way.
